contentrichtext.text: {{Unreferenced|date=December 2009}} The '''Whewell Professorship of International Law''' is a professorship in the [[University of Cambridge]]. The Professorship was established in 1868 by the will of the 19th-century [[scientist]] and moral [[philosopher]], [[William Whewell]], with a view to devising "such measures as may tend to diminish the causes of war and finally to extinguish war between nations". ==Incumbents of the Whewell Professorship of International Law== Holders of the Whewell chair have included three judges of the [[International Court of Justice]]. *1869: [[William Vernon Harcourt (politician)|William Vernon Harcourt]] *1887: Sir [[Henry Maine]] *1888: [[John Westlake]] *1908: [[Lassa Francis Lawrence Oppenheim]] *1920: [[Alexander Pearce Higgins]] *1935: [[Arnold Duncan McNair, 1st Baron McNair|Arnold McNair]] *1938: Sir [[Hersch Lauterpacht]] *1955: Sir [[Robert Yewdall Jennings|Robert Jennings]] *1981: Sir [[Derek Bowett]] *1992: Prof [[James Crawford (jurist)|James Crawford]] ==See also== *[[List of Professorships at the University of Cambridge]] {{DEFAULTSORT:Whewell Professor Of International Law}} [[Category:Professorships at the University of Cambridge]] [[Category:Professorships in law]] [[Category:1868 establishments in the United Kingdom]]
